notes: Appears to reduce joint pain and improve function.
Helps improve PMS symptoms.
source names: Archives of Gynecology and Obstetrics; The European Menopause Journal, Archives of Women's Mental Health, American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Electronic Physician

notes: HARMFUL. Never eat. Ingestion can causes diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance and kidney disfunction.
source names: Journal of Environmental Science and Health

notes: No high quality evidence to support aloe vera for treatment of wounds.
One study found diabetes patients with high blood levels of fat (dyslipidemia) benefited from one 300mg capsule every 12 hours for 2 months.
Slight evidence of reduced symptoms.
Evidence of anti-oxidants as treatment for male infertility is inconclusive.
Taking antixoxidants have no health benefits. In fact, beta carotene, vitamin A and vitamin E appear to increase the risk of death.
A review of 5 human trials concludes Ashwagandha reduces anxiety & stress. The review calls for more trials.
source names: The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine

notes: In a single pilot study on 46 men with low-sperm count, ashwagandha supplementation appeared to increase sperm count  & volume.
No solid evidence.
No human trials yet.
Limited studies suggest a stengthening of  the immune system. More evidence needed.
Low quality evidence for patients with chronic kidney disease when combined with conventional treatments.
No evidence
A study of high-dose benfotiamine (300 mg/day) supplementation over 24 months showed no significant effects.
There is no evidence that beta-carotene prevents cancer.
Compounds found in brewers' yeast and mushrooms. Most studies so far have been done in animals or test tubes, rather than on human subjects. Trials on human subjects are needed.
Reduced number of colds by 25% and severity of symptoms by 15%. Might increase the body's ability to fend off infections.
Not enough evidence to support using bitter melon in diabetes treament.
Insufficient evidence to claim that black cohosh improves menopause symptoms.
Reviews have found no association between black tea and ovarian or breast cancer risk.
Improves pain and function, and probably has no adverse effects.
A review of 27 studies found no evidence of efficacy.
Bromelain reduces arthritis symptoms. More research into dosage and side effects required.
source names:
Annals of Internal Medicine
Common Knowledge

notes: Butterbur extract may lower the frequency and severity of migraines.
Enhances consolidation of long term memories. Improves memory in young adults during their non-optimal time of day (mornings).
source names: Borota et al 2014, Frontiers in Psychology

notes: Population studies shows women who consume more than three cups of coffee a day MAY have a lower cancer risk than people who drink less than one cup per month.
Caffiene appears to slow cognitive decline and prevent Alzheimer's. But the results are not definitive.
High quality evidence has shown that extra calcium can slightly reduce blood pressure, especially in people younger than 35.
No evidence that calcium supplementation stops colorectal cancer itself, but it does inhibit potentially pre-cancerous colorectal polyps (adenomatous polyps)
Calcium supps might help to prevent fractures, although the results have been contradictory.
A review of 8 studies including 30,970 participants found that calcium plus vitamin D supplementation reduced total fracture risk by 15% and hip fracture risk by 30%.

sub_condition: breast cancer in premenopausal women, cancer
notes: There is no firm evidence that calcium and vitamin D supplementation decreases cancer risk.
Promising evidence showing a reduction in nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. The FDA has approved 2 synthetic cannabis drugs for treating chemo-related nausea.

Definitely lowers eye pressure, but only temporarily (3-4hrs). Since Glaucoma is a long-term disease, a LOT of cannabis would be required to maintain low pressure levels. Also, cannabis might cause additional damage to the eye by restricting blood flow to the optic nerve.

2 studies involving a total of 790 subjects showed positive results. Improved muscle spasms, pain, sleep quality, and mobility. Cannabis-based drug Sativex is approved for use in MS patients in 30 countries.
Several good quality trials have shown cannabinoids to be modestly effective in treating chronic pain. The harms and side-effects may outweigh the benefits though. Larger and longer trials needed.
source names: British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, Cochrane

notes: Capsaicin comes from chili peppers. Evidence has found that inhaling 4 micrograms at least 5 times a day can reduce inflammation, but the quality of the evidence is low. Who wants to inhale chilli?
Promising results in mice and in cell studies, but no human trials yet.
No human trials.
No high-quality human trials.

Chemicals known as flavanols, found in cocoa products, are thought to widen blood vessels and cause a minor drop in blood pressure. Further trials are needed to ascertain long-term efficacy. Does not apply to mllk chocolate.
Significantly decreases blood pressure, blood glucose, and some cholesterols.
Might lower blood glucose levels. It might also help with fat loss, which could benefit those with diabetes.
No more effective than placebo in controlling glucose levels.
30ml of coconut oil per day might help to reduce waist size, but possibly because the fat in coconut oil isn't as easily stored.
A metastudy found that the more coffee a person drinks, the lower their risk of cardiovascular disease. The optimum amount of coffee for this benefit was 3-5 per day.
A large statistical study of over 650,000 people found that coffee drinking reduced all cause mortality, whether it was instant, ground, or decaffeinated.
A few small human studies suggest possible effects on Alzheimers.
source names: The Journal of Nutritional Health and Aging

notes: CoQ10 improves insulin secretion in those with type 2 diabetes. However, human trials have been tiny.
Some tentative evidence on migraine sensitivity. But much more research needed.
Pooled data from two trials showed that CoQ10 did not affect blood pressure compared to placebo.
No statistically significant evidence that cranberry juice or supplements prevent UTIs.
Creatine doesn't have a significant effect in those with normal brain function, but it can benefit those with impaired brain function when combined with CoQ10.
Dandelion might have antimicrobial properties, which could help with throat infections.
Devil's Claw extract can reduce lower back pain by blocking the pathways that cause joint inflammation.
DHEA might improve memory in young men.
DHEA has no beneficial impact on body composition, performance etc.
HARMFUL. Long term safety data is non-existent. May increase risk of cancer.
Echinacea might have a slight impact on preventing and treating colds, but the results are statistically insignificant.
There's evidence that seaweed supplements can combat several mechanisms behind the onset of cardiovascular disease. Ecklonia in particular has been shown to decrease cholesterol.
Egg shell membrane eases joints by increasing cell production and decreasing inflammation. 500mg a day gives rapid results.
Eelderberry extract Sambucol may be useful for the treatment of viral influenza infections. More rigorous studies needed.
No good quality evidence for elk velvet antler as a treatment for arthritis.
Evening primrose oil is no more effective than placebo.
source names: Journal of Psychosomatic Obstetrics and Gynecology

notes: A review of 27 studies found no evidence of efficacy.
Feverfew reduces migraine frequency by just over half a migraine a month.
Evidence is poor.
In the largest and longest study of its kind, researchers found that fish oil/omega 3 had no statistically significant impact on cognitive decline.
source names: The Journal of the American Medical Association

notes: Review of trials found that people with asthma changing their diets to include more fish oil DID NOT improve their asthma.
Fish oil can counter chemotherapy-related damage to white blood cells.
Fish oil supplementation has a very minor positive impact on some measures of learning and performance.
It is thought that omega 3 reduces the risk of colorectal cancer and is effective in its treatment.
No beneficial effect for those with Crohn's Disease.
A small study of 211 men it was found that omega 3 supplementation significantly increased sperm count.
Probably no beneficial effect for those with type 2 diabetes.
HAMRFUL? Recent studies have linked fish oil intake with increased prostate cancer risk.
source names: Journal of the National Cancer Institutue.

notes: In one study, supplementation delayed the onset of psychosis in those on track to develop certain mental health conditions.
Low quality evidence.
A meta-analysis concluded that preterm birth & early preterm birth were reduced in women receiving omega-3.
Population studies indicate a slight possibility flaxeed could reduce breast cancer tumour growth. No controlled trials have been carried out.
Folic acid helps to prevent birth defects, but timing of supplementation is important.
POTENTIALLY HARMFUL. When combined with vitamin B12 can be associated with increased cancer risk.
Some suggestive evidence for effect on anxiety & stress.
Garlic might reduce blood pressure, but further research is required.
Due to anticancer properties of aged garlic, its consumption along with healthy diet may have beneficial effects on cancer. More clinical trials necessary.
Garlic might prevent certain cancers, but there is a lack of clinical trial evidence. The WHO recommends consuming at least one clove a day for general health benefits.
Insufficient evidnce for effects on the common cold.
source names: Cochrane: Garlic for the common cold

notes: Ginger prevents nausea and vomitting for some people in certain circumstances.
Insufficient clinical trial evidence for the use of ginkgo bilboa as a treatment for dementia.
source names: University of Oxford Medical Sciences Division

notes: No convincing evidence for ginseng enhancing cognition in healthy people, and only low quality evidence that it helps dementia patients.
Studies using a specific brand of glucosamine (Rotta) found that patients' pain decreased. However, studies using other brands found no difference between glucosamine and placebo.
Insufficient evidence to determine whether glutamine supplements are beneficial or harmful.
No evidence.
Supplementation for 90 days appeared to show some improvements in eye-health for seniors. But more research is needed.
Some preliminary evidence
The evidence is conflicting. However, drinking 3-5 cups a day might have general health benefits.
Might help to reduce total cholesterol levels, but trials were small and exposed to bias.
Mixed results, with some studies showing no effect and others suggesting positive benefits. Larger, longer-term trials are needed.
source names: Cochrane; BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine; Phytotherapy Research

notes: Hawthorn improves heart function in those with chronic heart failure.
A small, old study showed horsetail improved bone density in menopausal women.
Horse chestnut seed extract is effective in treating chronic venous insufficiency. However, further research is needed.
Injected hyaluronic acid might have a small effect in the treatment of osteoarthritis. However, the trials are biased and the results questionable.
Iron supplementation in infants might benefit their psychomotor development, but not their mental or behavioural development.
Reduces iron deficiency anaemia for pregnant women. The impact on babies is less clear.
Might have a small but significant effect on anxiety, but more information is required about the safety of long-term use.
Krill oil significantly reduced both emotional and physical PMS symptoms in one study.
One study found that L-arginine had a significant beneficial impact on exercise performance. However, the trial was tiny.
May alleviate pain in patients with diabetic nerve issues (neuropathy).
No evidence that lysine has a preventative effect on cold sores.
Suggestive evidence for reduced anxiety. No effect on depression.
One small study found inhaling lavender before bed relieves sleepiness on waking in healthy adults, but the trial was tiny.
One study found drinking leucine solution while exercising speeds up recovery, but the trial was tiny.
This combination of Chinese herbs may reduce pain, but does not provide any other significant benefits (e.g. antiinflammatory).
Taking lutein alone (or combined with zeaxanthin) may have little or no effect on progression to late AMD and vision loss (low-certainty evidence).
Insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of lycopene in preventing prostate cancer.
Low levels of magnesium in the diet are linked to high blood pressure and cholesterol. Magnesium treatment might be effective as a preventative.
Children with ADHD tend to have low magnesium and vitamin B6 levels. It's unclear whether supplementation reduces the symptoms of ADHD.
Can help to regulate the body-clock and improve sleep. However, it does not affect all groups of people in the same way, and the evidence is low quality.
Might be beneficial in treating hepatitis and other liver diseases, and protecting the liver from the impact of diabetes. However, the trials were low quality.
Some preliminary evidence for improving quality of life in breast cancer patients. Evidence for other cancers is weak. More studies needed.
Associated with slight reduction in pain and improvement in function, but the results may not be clinically significant.
Potential benefit for reducing the incidence of gestational diabetes.
Problems with glutamate function in the brain are thought to affect addiction and compulsive behaviour. NAC might improve glutamate function.
Might be effective in treating urinary issues in men by reducing inflammation. But we could find no recent studies.
POTENTIALLY HARMFUL. Has long been thought an effective treatment for heart disease, but recent findings show that it does not help, and can have severe adverse effects.
source names: The New England Journal of Medicine.

notes: One study found  beneficial effects on vascular health, although the trial was small.
Insufficient evidence to suggest omega 3 has any beneficial effect on children with ADHD.
Insufficient evidence to claim that omega 3 has any impact on heart health, either in healthy people or those with cardiovascular disease.
One study found that omega 6 prevented tumours from growing, but this was a cell study, i.e. not tested on humans.
source names: Journal of the National Cancer Institute

notes: No benefit on heart health.
HARMFUL. Highly toxic. If used at all, should be used with extreme caution.
Relaxes muscles, which relieves IBS-related muscle spasms. Peppermint oil might be more effective than conventional anti-spasmodics and fibre treatment.
Evidence does not support the use of piracetam as a treatment for cognitive impairment.
Medication that prevents potassium loss has no significant impact on blood pressure at low doses. Trials at high doses are unavailable.
Very low quality evidence. High quality trials needed.
Conflicting evidence and unclear results.
A particular probiotic (B. infantis 35624) improves IBS symptoms such as pain, bloating, and bowel movement difficulty. Evidence for other types of probiotic is limited.
No significant evidence that probiotics are any more effective than placebo in treating UTIs. Quality of evidence is poor.
Effective for preventing diarrhea associated with antibiotic use
Possible effect on recovery from chemotherapy. But studies were small and there were some quality concerns.
Resveratrol may have cardioprotective benefits, although scientists don't know quite how it works.
No human trials as yet.
Some preliminary evidence for relieving diabetes symptoms.
Rhodiola rosea L. is effective in treating fatigue. However, the quality of the trials conducted is questionable.
Possible anti-depressant effect. But solid evidence is lacking.
source names: Journal of Affective Disorders, Phytomedicine, Journal of Ethnopharmacology, Journal of Integrative Medicine, Human Psychopharmacology

notes: A review of eight studies showed no strong evidence of the effectiveness of SAM-e when taken on its own. More study needed.
No evidence that it improves urinary-tract-related problems.
Insufficient evidence that selenium lowers cancer risk.
Silicic acid might help to prevent Alzheimer's Disease by decreasing the amount of aluminium in the body. We await more research.
No clinical evidence for sore throats.
Very preliminary evidence shows Spirulina reducing blood pressure and lower lipids.
St John's Wort performs better than a placebo in improving depression symptoms, and not significantly different to antidepressants, which had more side-effects.
Daily treatment with St. John's wort had no effect on the emotional and physical symptoms of PMS.
No human trials.
No significant effect on metabolism in humans.
Tryptophan and 5-HTP might alleviate depression, but the studies conducted are unreliable, and the safety of the substances is questionable.
Might have anti-cancer effects, particularly on colon and pancreatic cancer, cervical neoplasia and Barrets metaplasia.
May be an effective therapy for peptic ulcers and ulcerative colitis when combined with conventional medications. However, larger trials are needed.
May have benefits. However, it has poor bioavailability. 9-20 teaspoons daily would be required to get the desired effect.
source names: Journal of the American Medical Directors Association, Journal of Affective Disorders, Phytotherapy Research, European Neuropsychopharmacology, Journal of Clinical Pharmacology,

notes: A high quality, long-term (18 months), but small study (40 subjects) found that 90mg of curcumin twice daily improved memory in adults without dementia.
Evidence suggests that tyrosine intake slightly improves working memory and information processing in healthy adults under strain.
Tyrosine may help with mental health problems by maintaining neurotransmitters, which affect mood.
One study found no difference between valerian and placebo in the treatment of anxiety. Research using larger samples is required.
HARMFUL? No significant differences between valerian and placebo in the treatment of insomnia. Valerian might have a number of adverse side effects.

Reduces overall risk of death and death due to diarrhoea by 12%. Vitamin A does not specifically reduce death due to measles, respiratory infections, or meningitis, but it can reduce new occurrences of diarrhoea and measles.
HARMFUL. High doses (10,000 ID/per day) can cause birth defects in human and animal infants.
Vitamin B treatment slows brain shrinkage and significantly reduces brain cell death.
source names: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

notes: A review of 18 studies found that vitamin B reduced psychiatric symptoms significantly more than in a control group.
May reduce the frequency of migraines.
May prevent skin cancer.
source names: International Journal of Cancer, Photodermatology, Photoimmunology & Photomedicine, CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians, New England Journal of Medicine

notes: Several small studies suggest anti-anxiety effects, but more research is needed.
The evidence for vitamin B8 (also known as Inositol) as a treatment for depression is unclear.

Vitamin C supplementation does not reduce the incidence of colds in the general population, although it can shorten their duration. For those under extreme physical stress (e.g. marathon runners) vitamin C appears to half the risk of developing a cold.
One of the largest & most rigorous trials ever conducted (25,871 participants over 5 years) found that vitamin D supplementation did not result in lower incidence of invasive cancers.
source names: PubMed, New England Journal of Medicine

notes: Some protection against severe asthma attacks in adults with mild to moderate asthma. Further trials focusing on children and people who experience frequent severe asthma attacks are needed.
It appears that supplementation for those with vitamin D deficiency increases bone density and helps to prevent fractures.
Low levels of vitamin D in the body are associated with depression, but whether or not vitamin D deficiency actually causes depression is uncertain.
The association between vitamin D status and diabetes is unclear.
In one trial, 10.8% of children taking vitamin D(3) contracted influenza, compared with 18.6% of children in the placebo group. It also reduced the number of flu-related asthma attacks.

A review suggests that vitamin D3 may reduce mortality, showing that about 150 participants need to be treated over five years for one additional life to be saved. It found some evidence that vitamin D3 seems to decrease mortality in elderly people not dependent on help or living in institutional care.
One of the largest & most rigorous trials ever conducted (over 83,000 participants) found that vitamin D supplementation did not result in lower incidence of cardiovascular events.
source names: JAMA, New England Journal of Medicine

notes: HARMFUL? High dosages might increase all-cause mortality. Small amounts can be beneficial, but the line between helpful and dangerous is unclear at this stage.
No to slight evidence.
More evidence needed.
No conclusive evidence.
source names: American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, OncoTarget

notes: Vitamin K2 has repeatedly been shown to improve bone strength, particularly in post-menopausal women.

Was found to reduce middle ear infections in otherwise healthy children by 8% (from 30% to 22%). It was administered via chewing gum, lozenges or syrup. Other studies have had similar positive results.
Some evidence that xylitol in toothpaste might reduce tooth decay by 13% over 3 years. The studies have been of low quality, though.
Oral zinc formulations may shorten symptoms of common cold infections. However, large high-quality trials are needed. Side effects can be common.
Zinc supplementation in children is associated with a reduction in the incidence and prevalence of pneumonia.
